title: 888 boss brushes off collapse of Bwin deal
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Sep 5, 2015, 00:11 BST - UK Markets closed 888 boss brushes off collapse of Bwin deal By Ben Martin | Telegraph – 2 hours 50 minutes ago -0.48 
The executive chairman of 888 says the spurned gambling company is already eyeing other acquisitions 
The boss of 888 has attemped to brush off the collapse of the gambling company’s takeover of Bwin.Party, claiming he is already working on other deals. 
Bwin confirmed that it had scrapped a deal with 888 in favour of a higher cash and shares takeover by GVC, worth £1.1bn on Thursday’s closing prices , or 129.64p a share. 
888 ruled out making another bid for Bwin and its executive chairman, Brian Mattingley, said the company has already been considering alternatives. 
“We’ve had bid targets in our mind for almost a year,” he said. “There are some people we’ve been talking to.” 
He added: “We have always stated our desire to have our own sportsbook. That will be quite a major focus going forward.” 
William Hill (Other OTC: WIMHF - news ) attempted a £720m takeover of 888 in February but the bid was knocked back by one of 888’s founders. 
There is speculation Hill may now have another tilt, but Mr Mattingley said: “Nothing has changed, we have one shareholder who is not a seller and he will remain in that position.” 
However, in a gambling industry in the grip of consolidation, there are few options for 888. Paddy Power (LSE: PAP.L - news ) is merging with Betfair and Ladbrokes (LSE: LAD.L - news ) is combining with Coral. 
Bwin investors will own two-thirds of the enlarged company following the GVC deal and will receive 25p in cash and rest in GVC shares, which closed 4pc lower at 435p. Bwin initially rose 3.7pc before finishing down 4.5pc at 110p and 888 edged up 0.3pc to 162.5p. 
Bwin boss Norbert Teufelberger will join GVC’s board as a non-executive.
